questions.question: What shot is this?

imageMetadata.resources: POV SHOT- When the camera becomes the 'eyes' of one particular character, seeing what they see.

questions.resources: POV SHOT- When the camera becomes the 'eyes' of one particular character, seeing what they see.

questions.question: What shot is this?

imageMetadata.resources: CU (CLOSE-UP)- Shows a character's face and shoulders. It is close enough to show subtle facial expressions clearly.

questions.resources: CU (CLOSE-UP)- Shows a character's face and shoulders. It is close enough to show subtle facial expressions clearly.

questions.question: What shot is this?

imageMetadata.resources: ECU (EXTREME CLOSE UP)- shows only a part of a character's face. It fills the screen with the details of a subject.

questions.resources: ECU (EXTREME CLOSE UP)- shows only a part of a character's face. It fills the screen with the details of a subject.

questions.question: What shots are these combined?

imageMetadata.resources:
TWO SHOT- Good for establishing a relationship between subjects
MS (MID SHOT)- Shows a character's upper-body, arms, and head. Allows room for hand gestures and a bit of movement.

questions.resources:
TWO SHOT- Good for establishing a relationship between subjects
MS (MID SHOT)- Shows a character's upper-body, arms, and head. Allows room for hand gestures and a bit of movement.

questions.question: What shot is this?

imageMetadata.resources: OVER THE SHOULDER SHOT- A close-up of a character as seen over the person in the foreground.

questions.resources: OVER THE SHOULDER SHOT- A close-up of a character as seen over the person in the foreground.

questions.question: What shot is this?

imageMetadata.resources: EST (ESTABLISHING SHOT)- Usually the first shot of a new scene, designed to show the audience where the action is taking place. It is usually a very wide shot or extreme wide shot.

questions.resources: EST (ESTABLISHING SHOT)- Usually the first shot of a new scene, designed to show the audience where the action is taking place. It is usually a very wide shot or extreme wide shot.

questions.question: What shot is this?

imageMetadata.resources: LS (LONG SHOT)- Used to show the human figure. A good considerable distance to let the viewers see the surroundings.

questions.resources: LS (LONG SHOT)- Used to show the human figure. A good considerable distance to let the viewers see the surroundings.

questions.question: What shot is this?

imageMetadata.resources: CUTAWAY- A shot that's usually of something other than the current action. It could be a different subject to add information/interest.

questions.resources: CUTAWAY- A shot that's usually of something other than the current action. It could be a different subject to add information/interest.

questions.question: What shot is this?

imageMetadata.resources: BIRD’S EYE- This shows a scene from directly overhead, a very unnatural and strange angle

questions.resources: BIRD’S EYE- This shows a scene from directly overhead, a very unnatural and strange angle

questions.question: What shot is this?

imageMetadata.resources: LOW ANGLE- The camera is placed below eye level, looking upward.

questions.resources: LOW ANGLE- The camera is placed below eye level, looking upward.

questions.question: What shot is this?

imageMetadata.resources: HIGH ANGLE- The camera is placed above eye level, looking downward.

questions.resources: HIGH ANGLE- The camera is placed above eye level, looking downward.

questions.question: What movement is this?

imageMetadata.resources: TRACKING/DOLLY SHOT- The camera is placed on a moving vehicle and moves alongside the action, generally following a moving figure or object

questions.resources: TRACKING/DOLLY SHOT- The camera is placed on a moving vehicle and moves alongside the action, generally following a moving figure or object

questions.question: What movement is this?

imageMetadata.resources: PAN/TILT- The camera rotates to aim upward or downward, left or right without changing the location (Good for a reveal)

questions.resources: PAN/TILT- The camera rotates to aim upward or downward, left or right without changing the location (Good for a reveal)

questions.question: What technique is this?

imageMetadata.resources: Dutch Tilt- Tilted to one side. Used for dramatic effect and helps portray disorientation, frantic or desperate action, intoxication, madness, etc.

questions.resources: Dutch Tilt- Tilted to one side. Used for dramatic effect and helps portray disorientation, frantic or desperate action, intoxication, madness, etc.

questions.question: Why are handheld shots important?

imageMetadata.resources: HAND-HELD- Denote a certain kind of gritty realism, and they can make the audience feel as though they are part of a scene “Fly on the wall”

questions.resources: HAND-HELD- Denote a certain kind of gritty realism, and they can make the audience feel as though they are part of a scene “Fly on the wall”
